<script type="text/javascript">
var maindomain_lang = 'https://www.paloaltonetworks.com';
var main_site_url = 'https://www.paloaltonetworks.com';
var ajax_url = 'https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-admin/admin-ajax.php';	
function getParameterByName(name, url) {
		if(url == null){
		  url = window.location.href;
		}
	    name = name.replace(/[\[\]]/g, '\\$&');
	    var regex = new RegExp('[?&]' + name + '(=([^&#]*)|&|#|$)'),
		results = regex.exec(url);
	    if (!results) return null;
	    if (!results[2]) return '';
	    return decodeURIComponent(results[2].replace(/\+/g, ' '));
	}
	var container_q = getParameterByName('container');
	var d_lang = 'en';	
</script>

<meta property="og:category_link" content="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/threat-research/"/>
<meta property="og:author" content="Amer Elsad"/>
<meta property="og:authorlink" content="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/author/"/>

<meta name="post_tags" content="bash,ClickFix,Phishing Kit,PowerShell,Remote Access Trojan"/>
<script type="application/ld+json">{"@context":"https:\/\/schema.org","@type":"BlogPosting","headline":"The ClickFix Factory: First Exposure of IUAM ClickFix Generator","name":"The ClickFix Factory: First Exposure of IUAM ClickFix Generator","description":"Unit 42 discovers ClickFix phishing kits, commoditizing social engineering. This kit presents a lowered barrier for inexperienced cybercriminals.","url":"https:\/\/unit42.paloaltonetworks.com\/clickfix-generator-first-of-its-kind\/","mainEntityOfPage":"https:\/\/unit42.paloaltonetworks.com\/clickfix-generator-first-of-its-kind\/","datePublished":"October 8, 2025","articleBody":"Executive Summary\r\nAttackers are packaging a highly effective social engineering technique known as ClickFix into easy-to-use phishing kits, making it accessible to a wider range of threat actors. This technique tricks victims into bypassing security measures by manually executing malware, typically information stealers and remote access Trojans (RATs). The commoditization of this technique follows the trend of phishing-as-a-service, lowering the skill and effort required to conduct successful attacks.\r\n\r\nWe have uncovered a phishing kit named the IUAM ClickFix Generator that automates the creation of these attacks. The kit is designed to generate highly customizable phishing pages that lure victims by mimicking browser verification challenges often used to block automated traffic. It includes advanced features such as operating system detection and clipboard injection, enabling low-effort, cross-platform malware deployment.\r\n\r\nWe have seen at least one campaign where attackers used pages generated by the IUAM ClickFix Generator to deploy the DeerStealer malware. Furthermore, our observation of several other pages with slight technical and visual differences points to a larger trend. This suggests adversaries are building a growing commercial ecosystem to monetize this technique through competing ClickFix-themed phishing kits.\r\n\r\nPalo Alto Networks customers are better protected from this activity through the following products and services:\r\n\r\n \tAdvanced URL Filtering and Advanced DNS Security identify known domains and URLs associated with this activity as malicious.\r\n \tThe Advanced WildFire machine-learning models and analysis techniques have been reviewed and updated in light of the indicators shared in this research.\r\n \tCortex XDR and XSIAM\r\n\r\nIf you think you might have been compromised or have an urgent matter, contact the Unit 42 Incident Response team.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nRelated Unit 42 Topics\r\nClickFix, Phishing\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nA Glimpse Behind the Curtain: The ClickFix Assembly Line\r\nWe identified a publicly exposed phishing kit generator hosted on an HTTP server at IP address 38.242.212[.]5, first observed on July 18, 2025. It remained active through early October.\r\n\r\nThe server hosts a web application on TCP port 3000, developed using the Express framework and styled with Tailwind CSS. The application serves an HTML page titled IUAM ClickFix Generator.\r\n\r\nThis tool allows threat actors to create highly customizable phishing pages that mimic the challenge-response behavior of a browser verification page commonly deployed by Content Delivery Networks (CDNs) and cloud security providers to defend against automated threats. The spoofed interface is designed to appear legitimate to victims, increasing the effectiveness of the lure.\r\n\r\nAn actor can configure every detail through a simple user interface (Figure 1), including:\r\n\r\n \tSite and message configuration\r\n\r\n \tAllows customization of the phishing page title (default: \u201cJust a moment\u2026\u201d) and domain\r\n \tIncludes editable page message, widget text, footer notes and success or error prompts to lure or instruct victims\r\n\r\n\r\n \tClipboard configuration\r\n\r\n \tDefines the content automatically copied to the victim\u2019s clipboard upon clicking verification prompts, typically a malicious command for them to paste and execute\r\n\r\n\r\n \tMobile blocking and security popover\r\n\r\n \tDetects mobile access and prompts victims to switch to desktop browsers and edit the core instructional component presented to them (security popover)\r\n\r\n\r\n \tAdvanced settings\r\n\r\n \tEnables obfuscation techniques and automatic clipboard-copy JavaScript injection\r\n \tIncludes OS detection to tailor commands for Windows (Command Prompt or PowerShell) or macOS (Terminal)\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_160157\" align=\"alignnone\" width=\"1000\"] Figure 1. User interface for the IUAM ClickFix Generator phishing kit.[\/caption]\r\nFrom the Factory to the Frontlines: Real-World Campaigns\r\nOur analysis indicates that attackers have used the identified phishing kit (or closely related variants) to generate a range of ClickFix-themed phishing pages. These pages share a consistent visual theme spoofing the browser verification challenges commonly deployed by CDN and web security platforms. These pages also leverage tailored OS detection and command-copy mechanisms to socially engineer victims into manually executing malware payloads.\r\n\r\nHowever, not all phishing pages identified share the same structure or behavior. While we confirmed at least one case where attackers delivered DeerStealer using a page this tool generated, we also saw several other phishing pages that differ slightly in technical implementation and visual design. These differences include:\r\n\r\n \tStructural variations in the HTML\/DOM layout\r\n \tModified or entirely different command copy mechanisms\r\n \tLack of specific JavaScript logic (e.g., OS detection, dynamic instructions)\r\n \tSimplified or inconsistent spoofing of browser challenge pages\r\n\r\nThese discrepancies suggest there are multiple variants of the ClickFix kit, or there could be distinct phishing toolkits inspired by the same lure concept but built independently or derived from earlier versions.\r\n\r\nBelow are examples showcasing the range of ClickFix phishing pages we discovered, each demonstrating slightly different levels of sophistication, behavior and delivery mechanisms.\r\nCampaign 1: The Windows-Only Attack (DeerStealer)\r\nIn one campaign, attackers configured the kit for a focused attack on Windows users. The threat actor included no OS detection logic in this setup. As a result, they didn\u2019t configure the page to provide alternative commands or specific instructions for macOS or other non-Windows users.\r\n\r\nWhen a victim interacts with the CAPTCHA element (Figure 2) by clicking a checkbox to determine whether they are human, this action triggers a background JavaScript to copy a malicious PowerShell command to their clipboard. Simultaneously, a popover appears, instructing them to open the Windows Run dialog (by pressing Win+R), paste the content from their clipboard and run the command. Once they follow these instructions, the command downloads and runs a multi-stage batch script that ultimately installs the DeerStealer infostealer.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_160168\" align=\"alignnone\" width=\"1000\"] Figure 2. Campaign 1 - ClickFix page delivering DeerStealer.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nFigure 3 below shows the copied command we observed.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_160179\" align=\"alignnone\" width=\"1000\"] Figure 3. DOM structure showing the command copied to victim clipboard.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nWhen executed, this command downloads a batch script cv.bat (SHA256: 2b74674587a65cfc9c2c47865ca8128b4f7e47142bd4f53ed6f3cb5cf37f7a6b) to the victim's temporary directory and immediately runs it.\r\n\r\nAnalysis of the batch script reveals a multi-stage process designed to download and execute a malicious MSI file (SHA256: ead6b1f0add059261ac56e9453131184bc0ae2869f983b6a41a1abb167edf151) identified as the DeerStealer infostealer.\r\nCampaign 2: Multi-Platform Attack (Odyssey Infostealer)\r\nIn another case we observed (Figure 4), the threat actor deployed three variations of the phishing page. These all ultimately lead to the delivery of Odyssey infostealer for macOS users and an as-yet unidentified malware strain for Windows users. Despite these variations, the core structure of the phishing page remained consistent.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_160190\" align=\"alignnone\" width=\"614\"] Figure 4. Campaign 2 - ClickFix page delivering Odyssey for macOS.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nEach version of the phishing page detects the victim\u2019s operating system via JavaScript, specifically by parsing the browser\u2019s navigator.userAgent string, and delivers a payload accordingly.\r\n\r\nWhile the visible text (Figure 4) suggests a harmless string, clicking the Copy button executes JavaScript that places a malicious command into the clipboard, not the one visually displayed.\r\n\r\nThe specific commands and targets vary between different versions of this phishing page.\r\n\r\nVariation 1: Multi-platform Windows and macOS Payload\r\n\r\n\r\nIn multi-platform variants, attackers serve Windows users a malicious PowerShell command designed to download and execute an unidentified malware strain. They serve macOS users a Base64-encoded command to deliver Odyssey (Figure 5).\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_160201\" align=\"alignnone\" width=\"1000\"] Figure 5. DOM structure showing a multi-platform example.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nExamples of domains that hosted this variant include:\r\n\r\n \ttradingview.connect-app[.]us[.]com\r\n \ttreadingveew.dekstop-apps[.]com\r\n \ttreadingveew.last-desk[.]org\r\n\r\nVariation 2: macOS-Targeted Variant with Windows Decoy and Fallback Handling\r\nIn other variants that appear to be macOS-focused, macOS users receive a Base64-encoded command to deliver Odyssey. Windows users receive a PowerShell command as a benign decoy intended to complete the social engineering lure without delivering a payload. These PowerShell commands sometimes use domains with Cyrillic characters that visually mimic Latin ones to appear legitimate (Figure 6 and 7).\r\n\r\nAnd for people using unknown operating systems (i.e., when OS detection fails), the phishing page displays a benign-looking command that also results in no malicious activity (Figure 6 and 7).\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_160212\" align=\"alignnone\" width=\"1000\"] Figure 6. DOM structure of the phishing page showing OS conditioned commands.[\/caption]\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_160223\" align=\"alignnone\" width=\"1000\"] Figure 7. DOM structure of the phishing page showing OS conditioned commands.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nExamples of domains that hosted this variant include:\r\n\r\n \tclaudflurer[.]com\r\n \tteamsonsoft[.]com\r\n\r\nVariation 3: macOS Exclusive Delivering Odyssey Only\r\nAnother variant appears to be exclusively macOS-focused, providing only a single Base64-encoded command that downloads and executes Odyssey, with no configurations for other operating systems (Figure 8).\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_160234\" align=\"alignnone\" width=\"1000\"] Figure 8. macOS-focused example with no OS specification.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nThis command downloads and executes a macOS Odyssey infostealer. It also uses nohup bash, which starts a new Bash shell in the background that ignores hang ups (HUP signals), so it keeps running even if the terminal is closed.\r\n\r\nExamples of domains or IP addresses that hosted this variant include:\r\n\r\n \temailreddit[.]com\r\n \thxxps[:]\/\/188.92.28[.]186\r\n \tcloudlare-lndex[.]com\r\n \ttradingviewen[.]com\r\n\r\nShared Origins and Developer Artifacts\r\nDespite differences in targeting logic and payload delivery URLs, all analyzed phishing pages in Campaign 2 share an identical underlying structure, including a consistent HTML layout and JavaScript function naming.\r\n\r\nFurthermore, while the specific command-and-control (C2) server address varied between the pages, Our analysis confirmed that, although the specific command-and-control (C2) server address varied between pages, all were Odyssey C2 servers.\r\n\r\nThis consistency in both the page structure and C2 infrastructure strongly suggests that these variants are part of the same activity cluster and likely originate from a shared codebase or builder tool.\r\n\r\nOdyssey is a malware-as-a-service (MaaS) offering operated by a cybercrime actor active on dark web forums such as Exploit and XSS, known to collaborate with other actors and affiliates. As such, it is plausible that these phishing page variations reflect customized deployments of a base toolkit distributed by the malware operator or their affiliates.\r\n\r\nAccording to posts published by the actor who advertises and operates the Odyssey MaaS, the actor has allegedly supplied ClickFix-style lure pages to affiliates upon request. This further supports the theory that these variants originate from a common generator tool but are tailored per affiliate, campaign or individual preferences.\r\n\r\nAdditionally, some pages contained leftover developer comments written in Russian (Figure 9 and 10).\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_160245\" align=\"alignnone\" width=\"718\"] Figure 9. Russian leftover developer comment.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nEnglish translation of this Russian comment in Figure 9: Add a call to stats.php when the page loads.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_160256\" align=\"alignnone\" width=\"756\"] Figure 10. Russian leftover developer comment.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nEnglish translation of the Russian comment in Figure 10: Function for sending click notification.\r\n\r\nUltimately, the structural consistency across all samples strongly indicates they were generated from a single, configurable phishing kit, with every malicious variant designed to deliver the Odyssey infostealer malware.\r\nConclusion\r\nThe discovery of the IUAM ClickFix Generator provides a rare glimpse into the tooling that lowers the barrier to entry for cybercriminals, enabling them to launch sophisticated, multi-platform attacks without deep technical expertise. The ClickFix technique's effectiveness relies on exploiting a user's instinct to follow onscreen instructions from what appears to be a trusted security provider.\r\n\r\nThis threat underscores the importance of user awareness and vigilance. Individuals and organizations should be cautious of any website that instructs them to manually copy and execute commands to prove they are human. This simple but deceptive social engineering tactic is a growing threat that turns a person\u2019s actions into the primary infection vector.\r\nPalo Alto Networks Protection and Mitigation\r\nPalo Alto Networks customers are better protected from the threats discussed above through the following products:\r\n\r\n \tAdvanced URL Filtering and Advanced DNS Security identify known domains and URLs associated with this activity as malicious.\r\n \tThe Advanced WildFire machine-learning models and analysis techniques have been reviewed and updated in light of the indicators shared in this research.\r\n \tCortex XDR and XSIAM are designed to prevent the malware samples described in this post by employing the Malware Prevention Engine. This approach combines several layers of protection, including Advanced WildFire, Behavioral Threat Protection and the Local Analysis module, to prevent both known and unknown malware from causing harm to endpoints. The mitigation methods implement malware protection based on different operating systems: Windows, macOS and Linux.\r\n\r\nIf you think you may have been compromised or have an urgent matter, get in touch with the Unit 42 Incident Response team or call:\r\n\r\n \tNorth America: Toll Free: +1 (866) 486-4842 (866.4.UNIT42)\r\n \tUK: +44.20.3743.3660\r\n \tEurope and Middle East: +31.20.299.3130\r\n \tAsia: +65.6983.8730\r\n \tJapan: +81.50.1790.0200\r\n \tAustralia: +61.2.4062.7950\r\n \tIndia: 000 800 050 45107\r\n\r\nPalo Alto Networks has shared these findings with our fellow Cyber Threat Alliance (CTA) members. CTA members use this intelligence to rapidly deploy protections to their customers and to systematically disrupt malicious cyber actors. Learn more about the Cyber Threat Alliance.\r\nIndicators of Compromise\r\nTable 1 lists SHA256 hashes for 18 Odyssey malware samples and eight DeerStealer samples associated with the ClickFix activity from this threat research article.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nSHA256 Hash\r\nMalware\r\n\r\n\r\n397ee604eb5e20905605c9418838aadccbbbfe6a15fc9146442333cfc1516273\r\nOdyssey\r\n\r\n\r\n7a8250904e6f079e1a952b87e55dc87e467cc560a2694a142f2d6547ac40d5e1\r\nOdyssey\r\n\r\n\r\n7765e5e0a7622ff69bd2cee0a75f2aae05643179b4dd333d0e75f98a42894065\r\nOdyssey\r\n\r\n\r\nd81cc9380673cb36a30f2a84ef155b0cbc7958daa6870096e455044fba5f9ee8\r\nOdyssey\r\n\r\n\r\n9c5920fa25239c0f116ce7818949ddce5fd2f31531786371541ccb4886c5aeb2\r\nOdyssey\r\n\r\n\r\n9090385242509a344efd734710e60a8f73719130176c726e58d32687b22067c8\r\nOdyssey\r\n\r\n\r\n8ed8880f40a114f58425e0a806b7d35d96aa18b2be83dede63eff0644fd7937d\r\nOdyssey\r\n\r\n\r\n7881a60ee0ad02130f447822d89e09352b084f596ec43ead78b51e331175450f\r\nOdyssey\r\n\r\n\r\nd375bb10adfd1057469682887ed0bc24b7414b7cec361031e0f8016049a143f9\r\nOdyssey\r\n\r\n\r\n039f82e92c592f8c39b9314eac1b2d4475209a240a7ad052b730f9ba0849a54a\r\nOdyssey\r\n\r\n\r\n82b73222629ce27531f57bae6800831a169dff71849e1d7e790d9bd9eb6e9ee7\r\nOdyssey\r\n\r\n\r\nd110059f5534360e58ff5f420851eb527c556badb8e5db87ddf52a42c1f1fe76\r\nOdyssey\r\n\r\n\r\n816bf9ef902251e7de73d57c4bf19a4de00311414a3e317472074ef05ab3d565\r\nOdyssey\r\n\r\n\r\n72633ddb45bfff1abeba3fc215077ba010ae233f8d0ceff88f7ac29c1c594ada\r\nOdyssey\r\n\r\n\r\ncd78a77d40682311fd30d74462fb3e614cbc4ea79c3c0894ba856a01557fd7c0\r\nOdyssey\r\n\r\n\r\n00c953a678c1aa115dbe344af18c2704e23b11e6c6968c46127dd3433ea73bf2\r\nOdyssey\r\n\r\n\r\nfe8b1b5b0ca9e7a95b33d3fcced833c1852c5a16662f71ddea41a97181532b14\r\nOdyssey\r\n\r\n\r\n966108cf5f3e503672d90bca3df609f603bb023f1c51c14d06cc99d2ce40790c\r\nOdyssey\r\n\r\n\r\n029a5405bbb6e065c8422ecc0dea42bb2689781d03ef524d9374365ebb0542f9\r\nDeerStealer\r\n\r\n\r\n081921671d15071723cfe979633a759a36d1d15411f0a6172719b521458a987d\r\nDeerStealer\r\n\r\n\r\n2b74674587a65cfc9c2c47865ca8128b4f7e47142bd4f53ed6f3cb5cf37f7a6b\r\nDeerStealer\r\n\r\n\r\n6e4119fe4c8cf837dac27e2948ce74dc7af3b9d4e1e4b28d22c4cf039e18b993\r\nDeerStealer\r\n\r\n\r\nba5305e944d84874bde603bf38008675503244dc09071d19c8c22ded9d4f6db4\r\nDeerStealer\r\n\r\n\r\nf2a068164ed7b173f17abe52ad95c53bccf3bb9966d75027d1e8960f7e0d43ac\r\nDeerStealer\r\n\r\n\r\n3aee8ad1a30d09d7e40748fa36cd9f9429e698c28e2a1c3bcf88a062155eee8c\r\nDeerStealer\r\n\r\n\r\nead6b1f0add059261ac56e9453131184bc0ae2869f983b6a41a1abb167edf151\r\nDeerStealer\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nTable 1. Malware samples associated with the ClickFix campaigns from this article.\r\n\r\nTable 2 lists the IPv4 addresses for C2 servers used by Odyssey malware samples from this article.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nIP Address\r\nFirst Seen\r\nLast Seen\r\nMalware\r\n\r\n\r\n45.146.130[.]129\r\n2025-07-22\r\n2025-07-28\r\nOdyssey\r\n\r\n\r\n45.135.232[.]33\r\n2025-06-15\r\n2025-07-18\r\nOdyssey\r\n\r\n\r\n83.222.190[.]214\r\n2025-05-23\r\n2025-08-10\r\nOdyssey\r\n\r\n\r\n194.26.29[.]217\r\n2025-06-22\r\n2025-06-24\r\nOdyssey\r\n\r\n\r\n88.214.50[.]3\r\n2025-04-14\r\n2025-05-16\r\nOdyssey\r\n\r\n\r\n45.146.130[.]132\r\n2025-07-01\r\n2025-07-28\r\nOdyssey\r\n\r\n\r\n45.146.130[.]131\r\n2025-07-03\r\n2025-07-28\r\nOdyssey\r\n\r\n\r\n185.93.89[.]62\r\n2025-07-29\r\n2025-09-18\r\nOdyssey\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nTable 2. IPv4 addresses for C2 servers.\r\n\r\nTable 3 lists the fully qualified domain names (FQDNs) associated with the malware discussed in this article.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nDomain\r\nAssociated Malware\r\n\r\n\r\nOdyssey1[.]to\r\nOdyssey\r\n\r\n\r\nOdyssey-st[.]com\r\nOdyssey\r\n\r\n\r\nsdojifsfiudgigfiv[.]to\r\nOdyssey\r\n\r\n\r\nCharge0x[.]at\r\nOdyssey\r\n\r\n\r\nspeedtestcheck[.]org\r\nOdyssey\r\n\r\n\r\nclaudflurer[.]com\r\nOdyssey\r\n\r\n\r\nteamsonsoft[.]com\r\nOdyssey\r\n\r\n\r\nMacosapp-apple[.]com\r\nOdyssey\r\n\r\n\r\ntradingview.connect-app.us[.]com\r\nOdyssey\r\n\r\n\r\ntreadingveew.last-desk[.]org\r\nOdyssey\r\n\r\n\r\ntradingviewen[.]com\r\nOdyssey\r\n\r\n\r\nfinancementure[.]com\r\nOdyssey\r\n\r\n\r\nCryptoinfnews[.]com\r\nOdyssey\r\n\r\n\r\nEmailreddit[.]com\r\nOdyssey\r\n\r\n\r\nMacosxappstore[.]com\r\nOdyssey\r\n\r\n\r\nCryptoinfo-news[.]com\r\nOdyssey\r\n\r\n\r\nCryptoinfo-allnews[.]com\r\nOdyssey\r\n\r\n\r\napposx[.]com\r\nOdyssey\r\n\r\n\r\nttxttx[.]com\r\nOdyssey\r\n\r\n\r\nGreenpropertycert[.]com\r\nOdyssey\r\n\r\n\r\ncloudlare-lndex[.]com\r\nOdyssey\r\n\r\n\r\nDactarhome[.]com\r\nOdyssey\r\n\r\n\r\nibs-express[.]com\r\nOdyssey\r\n\r\n\r\nfavorite-hotels[.]com\r\nDeerStealer\r\n\r\n\r\nwatchlist-verizon[.]com\r\nDeerStealer\r\n\r\n\r\nGrowsearch[.]in\r\nDeerStealer\r\n\r\n\r\nCreatorssky[.]com\r\nDeerStealer\r\n\r\n\r\nquirkyrealty[.]com\r\nDeerStealer\r\n\r\n\r\nSharanilodge[.]com\r\nDeerStealer\r\n\r\n\r\nasmicareer[.]com\r\nDeerStealer\r\n\r\n\r\ncrm.jskymedia[.]com\r\nDeerStealer\r\n\r\n\r\ncoffeyelectric[.]com\r\nDeerStealer\r\n\r\n\r\nSifld.rajeshmhegde[.]com\r\nDeerStealer\r\n\r\n\r\nPixelline[.]in\r\nDeerStealer\r\n\r\n\r\ntechinnovhub[.]co[.]za\r\nDeerStealer\r\n\r\n\r\nfudgeshop[.]com[.]au\r\nDeerStealer\r\n\r\n\r\nevodigital[.]com[.]au\r\nDeerStealer\r\n\r\n\r\n365-drive[.]com\r\nDeerStealer\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nTable 3. FQDNs associated with the malware discussed in this article.\r\nNote: In some cases, the ClickFix-style phishing page is not hosted on a domain the threat actor registered, but instead injected into a legitimate website that they\u2019ve compromised. The actor adds a malicious JavaScript snippet that performs several DOM manipulations, including injecting the ClickFix phishing lure. They style this using Tailwind CSS, which overrides the site\u2019s original layout and appearance to fully render the phishing content in place of the legitimate one.","publisher":{"@type":"Organization","@id":"#panworg"},"image":{"@type":"ImageObject","url":"https:\/\/unit42.paloaltonetworks.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2025\/10\/03_Malware_Category_1920x900-300x300.jpg","width":300,"height":300},"speakable":{"@type":"SpeakableSpecification","xPath":["\/html\/head\/title","\/html\/head\/meta[@name='description']\/@content"]},"author":[{"@type":"Person","name":"Amer Elsad"}]}</script><link rel='stylesheet' id='crayon-css' href='https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/plugins/crayon-syntax-highlighter/css/min/crayon.min.css?ver=_2.7.2_beta' media='all' />

		#wpdevart_lb_information_content{
			width:100%;

		}
		#wpdevart_info_counter_of_imgs{
			    display: inline-block;
				padding-left:15px;
				padding-right:4px;
				font-size:20px;
				color:#000000;
		}
		#wpdevart_info_caption{
			    display: inline-block;
				padding-left:15px;
				padding-right:4px;
				font-size:20px;
				color:#000000;
		}
		#wpdevart_info_title{
			    display: inline-block;
				padding-left:5px;
				padding-right:5px;
				font-size:15px;
				color:#000000;
		}
		@-webkit-keyframes rotate {
			to   {-webkit-transform: rotate(360deg);}
			from  {-webkit-transform: rotate(0deg);}
		}
		@keyframes rotate {
			to   {transform: rotate(360deg);}
			from  {transform: rotate(0deg);}
		}
		#wpdevart_lb_loading_img,#wpdevart_lb_loading_img_first{
			-webkit-animation: rotate 2s linear  infinite;
    		animation: rotate 2s linear infinite;
		}
	  </style>      <link rel="icon" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/icon-Unit42-180x180-1.png" sizes="32x32" />
<link rel="icon" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/icon-Unit42-180x180-1.png" sizes="192x192" />
<link rel="apple-touch-icon" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/icon-Unit42-180x180-1.png" />

<script>var $ = jQuery;</script>

    <script type="text/javascript">
    ;(function(win, doc, style, timeout) {
    var STYLE_ID = 'at-body-style';
    function getParent() {
    return doc.getElementsByTagName('head')[0];
    }
    function addStyle(parent, id, def) {
        if (!parent) {
        return;
        }
        var style = doc.createElement('style');
        style.id = id;
        style.innerHTML = def;
        parent.appendChild(style);
    }
    function removeStyle(parent, id) {
        if (!parent) {
            return;
        }
        var style = doc.getElementById(id);
        if (!style) {
            return;
        }
        parent.removeChild(style);
    }
    addStyle(getParent(), STYLE_ID, style);
    setTimeout(function() {
    removeStyle(getParent(), STYLE_ID);
    }, timeout);
    }(window, document, "body {visibility:hidden !important}", 3000));
    </script>

            <script src="https://assets.adobedtm.com/9273d4aedcd2/0d76ae0322d7/launch-425c423d843b.min.js" async></script>
            <script type="text/javascript" src="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/content/dam/pan/en_US/includes/attribution.js"></script>


<script type="text/javascript">
var isIE11 = !!navigator.userAgent.match(/Trident.*rv\:11\./);
if(isIE11){
    var polyfill = 'https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/scripts/polyfill.min.js';
    document.write('<script type="text/javascript" src="'+polyfill+'">\x3C/script>');
}
    /**
 * String.prototype.replaceAll() polyfill
 * https://gomakethings.com/how-to-replace-a-section-of-a-string-with-another-one-with-vanilla-js/
 * @author Chris Ferdinandi
 * @license MIT
 */
if (!String.prototype.replaceAll) {
	String.prototype.replaceAll = function(str, newStr){
		// If a regex pattern
		if (Object.prototype.toString.call(str).toLowerCase() === '[object regexp]') {
			return this.replace(str, newStr);
		}
		// If a string
		return this.replace(new RegExp(str, 'g'), newStr);
	};
}

    /*! lozad.js - v1.16.0 - 2020-09-06 */
!function(t,e){"object"==typeof exports&&"undefined"!=typeof module?module.exports=e():"function"==typeof define&&define.amd?define(e):t.lozad=e()}(this,function(){"use strict";
/**
   * Detect IE browser
   * @const {boolean}
   * @private
   */var g="undefined"!=typeof document&&document.documentMode,f={rootMargin:"0px",threshold:0,load:function(t){if("picture"===t.nodeName.toLowerCase()){var e=t.querySelector("img"),r=!1;null===e&&(e=document.createElement("img"),r=!0),g&&t.getAttribute("data-iesrc")&&(e.src=t.getAttribute("data-iesrc")),t.getAttribute("data-alt")&&(e.alt=t.getAttribute("data-alt")),r&&t.append(e)}if("video"===t.nodeName.toLowerCase()&&!t.getAttribute("data-src")&&t.children){for(var a=t.children,o=void 0,i=0;i<=a.length-1;i++)(o=a[i].getAttribute("data-src"))&&(a[i].src=o);t.load()}t.getAttribute("data-poster")&&(t.poster=t.getAttribute("data-poster")),t.getAttribute("data-src")&&(t.src=t.getAttribute("data-src")),t.getAttribute("data-srcset")&&t.setAttribute("srcset",t.getAttribute("data-srcset"));var n=",";if(t.getAttribute("data-background-delimiter")&&(n=t.getAttribute("data-background-delimiter")),t.getAttribute("data-background-image"))t.style.backgroundImage="url('"+t.getAttribute("data-background-image").split(n).join("'),url('")+"')";else if(t.getAttribute("data-background-image-set")){var d=t.getAttribute("data-background-image-set").split(n),u=d[0].substr(0,d[0].indexOf(" "))||d[0];// Substring before ... 1x
u=-1===u.indexOf("url(")?"url("+u+")":u,1===d.length?t.style.backgroundImage=u:t.setAttribute("style",(t.getAttribute("style")||"")+"background-image: "+u+"; background-image: -webkit-image-set("+d+"); background-image: image-set("+d+")")}t.getAttribute("data-toggle-class")&&t.classList.toggle(t.getAttribute("data-toggle-class"))},loaded:function(){}};function A(t){t.setAttribute("data-loaded",!0)}var m=function(t){return"true"===t.getAttribute("data-loaded")},v=function(t){var e=1<arguments.length&&void 0!==arguments[1]?arguments[1]:document;return t instanceof Element?[t]:t instanceof NodeList?t:e.querySelectorAll(t)};return function(){var r,a,o=0<arguments.length&&void 0!==arguments[0]?arguments[0]:".lozad",t=1<arguments.length&&void 0!==arguments[1]?arguments[1]:{},e=Object.assign({},f,t),i=e.root,n=e.rootMargin,d=e.threshold,u=e.load,g=e.loaded,s=void 0;"undefined"!=typeof window&&window.IntersectionObserver&&(s=new IntersectionObserver((r=u,a=g,function(t,e){t.forEach(function(t){(0<t.intersectionRatio||t.isIntersecting)&&(e.unobserve(t.target),m(t.target)||(r(t.target),A(t.target),a(t.target)))})}),{root:i,rootMargin:n,threshold:d}));for(var c,l=v(o,i),b=0;b<l.length;b++)(c=l[b]).getAttribute("data-placeholder-background")&&(c.style.background=c.getAttribute("data-placeholder-background"));return{observe:function(){for(var t=v(o,i),e=0;e<t.length;e++)m(t[e])||(s?s.observe(t[e]):(u(t[e]),A(t[e]),g(t[e])))},triggerLoad:function(t){m(t)||(u(t),A(t),g(t))},observer:s}}});

</script>

        <div class="productNav2021Component dark default" id="PAN_2021_NAV_ASYNC">

<script type="text/javascript">
	function getCookie(cname) {
	 	var name = cname + "=";
  		var decodedCookie = decodeURIComponent(document.cookie);
		var ca = decodedCookie.split(';');
  		for(var i = 0; i <ca.length; i++) {
    			var c = ca[i];
    			while (c.charAt(0) == ' ') {
     				 c = c.substring(1);
    			}
    			if (c.indexOf(name) == 0) {
    				 return c.substring(name.length, c.length);
    			}
  		}
  		return "";
	}

	var referer = "";//sessionStorage.container;
	var pcontainer = sessionStorage.getItem("container");
	var searchResultsPagePath = "";
	if(((pcontainer) && pcontainer.indexOf('Prisma')!=-1)){
	    referer = 'Prisma' ;
	}        
        else if(((pcontainer) && pcontainer.indexOf('Cortex')!=-1)){
            if( pcontainer.indexOf('CloudCortex') != -1){
                referer = 'CloudCortex' ;
            }
            else{
                referer = 'Cortex' ;
            }	    
	}
        else if(((pcontainer) && pcontainer.indexOf('Sase')!=-1)){
	    referer = 'Sase' ;
	}
	else if(((pcontainer) && pcontainer.indexOf('Unit')!=-1)){
	    referer = 'Unit' ;
	}
	else if(((pcontainer) && pcontainer.indexOf('Ngfw')!=-1)){
	    referer = 'Ngfw' ;
	}
        var fromRef = document.referrer;
        var nContainer = getCookie("navContainer");
        if(nContainer){//If user is coming from main site, we need to reset the container		
		if(fromRef  && fromRef.indexOf("prismacloud.io")!=-1){
                        referer = 'Prisma' ;
                        sessionStorage.setItem("container","Prisma");
                } else if(fromRef.indexOf("paloaltonetworks.com")!=-1 || fromRef.indexOf("paloaltonetworks.jp")!=-1 ){
                        if(nContainer.indexOf('Prisma') != -1){
                            referer = 'Prisma' ;
                            sessionStorage.setItem("container","Prisma");
                        }
                        if(nContainer.indexOf('Cortex') != -1){
                            if( nContainer.indexOf('CloudCortex') != -1){
                                referer = 'CloudCortex';
                                sessionStorage.setItem("container","CloudCortex");
                            }
                            else{
                                referer = 'Cortex';
                                sessionStorage.setItem("container","Cortex");
                            }                            
                        }
			if(nContainer.indexOf('Sase') != -1){
                            referer = 'Sase' ;
                            sessionStorage.setItem("container","Sase");
                        }
			if(nContainer.indexOf('Unit') != -1){
                            referer = 'Unit' ;
                            sessionStorage.setItem("container","Unit");
                        }
			if(nContainer.indexOf('Ngfw') != -1){
                            referer = 'Ngfw' ;
                            sessionStorage.setItem("container","Ngfw");
                        }
			document.cookie = 'navContainer=; path=/; domain=.paloaltonetworks.com; expires=' + new Date(0).toUTCString();
		}
	}
if(referer != "Prisma" && referer != "CloudCortex" && referer != "Cortex" && referer != "Sase" && referer != "Unit" && referer != "Ngfw") {
    referer = 'Unit' ;
    sessionStorage.setItem("container","Unit");
}
function callMainSitePrismaNavHTML(){
    
    var referrer_domain = 'https://www.paloaltonetworks.com';
    sessionStorage.setItem("domain",referrer_domain);
    if(referer == 'Prisma'){
        //var menu_url = referrer_domain+'/_jcr_content/globals/cleanHeaderPrisma.prismaRenderer.html';
        var menu_url = 'https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/unit-nav-renderer.php?type=prisma&domain=en';
        searchResultsPagePath = referrer_domain+"/search/prismasearch";
        }
    if(referer == 'CloudCortex'){
        var menu_url = 'https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/unit-nav-renderer.php?type=cortexcloud&domain=en';
        searchResultsPagePath = referrer_domain+"/search/cortexcloudsearch";	
    }
    if(referer == 'Cortex'){
        //var menu_url = referrer_domain+'/_jcr_content/globals/cleanHeaderCortex.cortexRenderer.html';	
        var menu_url = 'https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/unit-nav-renderer.php?type=cortex&domain=en';	
        searchResultsPagePath = referrer_domain+"/search/cortexsearch";	
    }
    if(referer == 'Sase'){
        //var menu_url = referrer_domain+'/_jcr_content/globals/cleanHeaderSase.saseRenderer.html';
        var menu_url = 'https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/unit-nav-renderer.php?type=sase&domain=en';
        searchResultsPagePath = referrer_domain+"/search/sasesearch";
    }
    if(referer == 'Unit'){
        var menu_url = 'https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/unit-nav-renderer.php?type=unit42&domain=en';
        searchResultsPagePath = referrer_domain+"/content/pan/en_US/search/unit42search";
		    }
    if(referer == 'Ngfw'){
        //var menu_url = 'https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/ngfw-cdss-nav-renderer.php';
        var menu_url = 'https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/unit-nav-renderer.php?type=ngfw&domain=en'; 
        searchResultsPagePath = referrer_domain+"/search/ngfwcdsssearch";
    }
    httpGet(menu_url,'menu_html');
    document.getElementById('main-nav-menu-cont').removeAttribute("style");
}
function addStyle(styles) {            
    /* Create style document */
    var css = document.createElement('style');
    css.type = 'text/css';

    if (css.styleSheet) 
        css.styleSheet.cssText = styles;
    else 
        css.appendChild(document.createTextNode(styles));

    /* Append style to the tag name */
    document.getElementsByTagName("head")[0].appendChild(css);
}
function httpGet(theUrl,req_type) {
    if (window.XMLHttpRequest) { // code for IE7+, Firefox, Chrome, Opera, Safari
        xmlhttp=new XMLHttpRequest();
    } else {// code for IE6, IE5
        xmlhttp=new ActiveXObject("Microsoft.XMLHTTP");
    }
    xmlhttp.onreadystatechange=function()
    {
        if (xmlhttp.readyState==4 && xmlhttp.status==200)
        {
            if(req_type == 'menu_html'){
            var nav_text = xmlhttp.responseText.replaceAll('https://static.cloud.coveo.com/searchui/v2.9159/js/CoveoJsSearch.Lazy.min.js', '');
            nav_text = nav_text.replaceAll('src="/', 'src="'+maindomain_lang+'/');
            nav_text = nav_text.replaceAll("'/content", "'"+maindomain_lang+"/content");
                        
            document.getElementById("PAN_2021_NAV_ASYNC").innerHTML = nav_text.replaceAll('href="/', 'href="'+maindomain_lang+'/');

            var lozad_back = document.getElementsByClassName('lozad-background');
            Array.prototype.forEach.call(lozad_back, function(el) {
            // Do stuff here
            var el_back_img_path = el.getAttribute('data-background-image');
            var first_pos = el_back_img_path.indexOf("'");
            var last_pos = el_back_img_path.indexOf("'",first_pos+1);
            el_back_img_path = el_back_img_path.substring(first_pos+1,last_pos);
            el.setAttribute("data-background-image",main_site_url+el_back_img_path);
            });
            const observer_lozad = lozad('.lozad, .lozad-background'); // lazy loads elements with default selector as '.lozad'
            observer_lozad.observe();
            }
            if(req_type == 'head_inline_css'){
            addStyle(xmlhttp.responseText);
            }
        }
    }
    xmlhttp.open("GET", theUrl, true );
    xmlhttp.send();    
}    
    
if(referer == 'Prisma' || referer == 'CloudCortex' || referer == 'Cortex' || referer == 'Sase' || referer == 'Unit' || referer == 'Ngfw'){
    const article = document.querySelector('#PAN_2021_NAV_ASYNC');
    if(referer == 'Prisma'){
        article.dataset.type = 'prisma';
        $('#PAN_2021_NAV_ASYNC').removeClass('default').addClass('defaultRedesigned');
    }
    else if(referer == 'CloudCortex'){
        article.dataset.type = 'cloudcortex';
    }
    else if(referer == 'Cortex'){
        article.dataset.type = 'cortex';
    }
    else if(referer == 'Sase'){
        article.dataset.type = 'sase';
    }
    else if(referer == 'Unit'){
        article.dataset.type = 'unit';
    }
    else if(referer == 'Ngfw'){
        article.dataset.type = 'ngfw';
    }
    //set class to default
    if(referer == 'Unit' || referer == 'Ngfw'){
        $('#PAN_2021_NAV_ASYNC').removeClass('default').addClass('defaultRedesigned');
    }
    callMainSitePrismaNavHTML();
}
</script>
<!--  End: Scripts Migrated From Unit42-v5 -->

src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/strata_RGB_logo_Icon_Color.png" alt="Advanced URL Filtering icon">Advanced URL Filtering</a><a class="l-linkcard is-blue" data-page-track-value="clickfix-generator-first-of-its-kind:hero:Advanced WildFire"><img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/strata_RGB_logo_Icon_Color.png" alt="Advanced WildFire icon">Advanced WildFire</a><a class="l-linkcard is-blue" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/product-category/cloud-delivered-security-services/" style="--card-color: #ffcb06" role="link" title="Cloud-Delivered Security Services" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="clickfix-generator-first-of-its-kind:hero:Cloud-Delivered Security Services"><img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/strata_RGB_logo_Icon_Color.png" alt="Cloud-Delivered Security Services icon">Cloud-Delivered Security Services</a><a class="l-linkcard is-blue" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/product-category/cortex/" style="--card-color: #00cc66" role="link" title="Cortex" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="clickfix-generator-first-of-its-kind:hero:Cortex"><img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/cortex_RGB_logo_Icon_Color.png" alt="Cortex icon">Cortex</a><a class="l-linkcard is-blue" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/product-category/cortex-xdr/" style="--card-color: #00cc66" role="link" title="Cortex XDR" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="clickfix-generator-first-of-its-kind:hero:Cortex XDR"><img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/cortex_RGB_logo_Icon_Color.png" alt="Cortex XDR icon">Cortex XDR</a><a class="l-linkcard is-blue" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/product-category/cortex-xsiam/" style="--card-color: #00cc66" role="link" title="Cortex XSIAM" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="clickfix-generator-first-of-its-kind:hero:Cortex XSIAM"><img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/cortex_RGB_logo_Icon_Color.png" alt="Cortex XSIAM icon">Cortex XSIAM</a></div>              </div>
            </div>
          </div>
          <div class="ab__footer">
            <div class="l-container">
              <div class="ab__footer-wrapper">
                <ul class="ab__features" role="list">
                  <li role="listitem">
				 <img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/icon-profile-grey.svg" alt="Profile Icon">
					 <div class="ab__text"><span>By:</span><ul class="ab__tags"><li><a data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="clickfix-generator-first-of-its-kind:hero:Amer Elsad" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/author/amer-elsad/">Amer Elsad</a></li></ul></div></li>                  <li role="listitem">
			<img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/icon-calendar-grey.svg" alt="Published Icon">

		</li>                  <li role="listitem"><img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/icon-tags-grey.svg" alt="Tags Icon"><div class="ab__text"><span>Tags:</span><ul class="ab__tags"><li><a data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="clickfix-generator-first-of-its-kind:hero:bash" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/bash/">Bash</a></li><li><a data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="clickfix-generator-first-of-its-kind:hero:ClickFix" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/clickfix/">ClickFix</a></li><li><a data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="clickfix-generator-first-of-its-kind:hero:Phishing Kit" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/phishing-kit/">Phishing Kit</a></li><li><a data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="clickfix-generator-first-of-its-kind:hero:PowerShell" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/powershell/">PowerShell</a></li><li><a data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="clickfix-generator-first-of-its-kind:hero:Remote Access Trojan" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/remote-access-trojan/">Remote Access Trojan</a></li></ul></div>
		</li>                </ul>
                <div class="ab__options">
                  <ul role="list">

            </div>
          </div>
        </div>
      </section> 
    <section class="section blog-contents"> 
      <div class="pa blog-editor">
        <div class="l-container">
          <div class="be__wrapper">
            <div class="be__contents">
              <div class="be__contents-wrapper">
                <h2><a id="post-160134-_4lt92rr5muov"></a>Executive Summary</h2>
<p>Attackers are packaging a highly effective social engineering technique known as ClickFix into easy-to-use phishing kits, making it accessible to a wider range of threat actors. This technique tricks victims into bypassing security measures by manually executing malware, typically information stealers and remote access Trojans (RATs). The commoditization of this technique follows the trend of phishing-as-a-service, lowering the skill and effort required to conduct successful attacks.</p>
<p>We have uncovered a phishing kit named the IUAM ClickFix Generator that automates the creation of these attacks. The kit is designed to generate highly customizable phishing pages that lure victims by mimicking browser verification challenges often used to block automated traffic. It includes advanced features such as operating system detection and clipboard injection, enabling low-effort, cross-platform malware deployment.</p>
<p>We have seen at least one campaign where attackers used pages generated by the IUAM ClickFix Generator to deploy the DeerStealer malware. Furthermore, our observation of several other pages with slight technical and visual differences points to a larger trend. This suggests adversaries are building a growing commercial ecosystem to monetize this technique through competing ClickFix-themed phishing kits.</p>
<p>Palo Alto Networks customers are better protected from this activity through the following products and services:</p>
<ul>
<li><a href="https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/advanced-url-filtering/administration" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Advanced URL Filtering</a> and <a href="https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/dns-security" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Advanced DNS Security</a> identify known domains and URLs associated with this activity as malicious.</li>
<li>The <a href="https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/wildfire" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Advanced WildFire</a> machine-learning models and analysis techniques have been reviewed and updated in light of the indicators shared in this research.</li>
<li><a href="https://docs-cortex.paloaltonetworks.com/p/XDR" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Cortex XDR</a> and <a href="https://docs-cortex.paloaltonetworks.com/p/XSIAM">XSIAM</a></li>
</ul>
<p>If you think you might have been compromised or have an urgent matter, contact the <a href="https://start.paloaltonetworks.com/contact-unit42.html" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Unit 42 Incident Response team</a>.</p>
<table style="width: 100%;">
<thead>
<tr>
<td style="width: 35%;"><b>Related Unit 42 Topics</b></td>
<td style="width: 100%;"><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/clickfix/" target="_blank" rel="noopener"><b>ClickFix</b></a>, <strong><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/phishing/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Phishing</a></strong></td>
</tr>
</thead>
</table>
<h2><a id="post-160134-_wven14kmgum2"></a>A Glimpse Behind the Curtain: The ClickFix Assembly Line</h2>
<p>We identified a publicly exposed phishing kit generator hosted on an HTTP server at IP address <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">38.242.212[.]5</span>, first observed on July 18, 2025. It remained active through early October.</p>
<p>The server hosts a web application on TCP port 3000, developed using the Express framework and styled with Tailwind CSS. The application serves an HTML page titled IUAM ClickFix Generator.</p>
<p>This tool allows threat actors to create highly customizable phishing pages that mimic the challenge-response behavior of a browser verification page commonly deployed by Content Delivery Networks (CDNs) and cloud security providers to defend against automated threats. The spoofed interface is designed to appear legitimate to victims, increasing the effectiveness of the lure.</p>
<p>An actor can configure every detail through a simple user interface (Figure 1), including:</p>
<ul>
<li><strong>Site and message configuration</strong>
<ul>
<li>Allows customization of the phishing page title (default: “Just a moment…”) and domain</li>
<li>Includes editable page message, widget text, footer notes and success or error prompts to lure or instruct victims</li>
</ul>
</li>
<li><strong>Clipboard configuration</strong>
<ul>
<li>Defines the content automatically copied to the victim’s clipboard upon clicking verification prompts, typically a malicious command for them to paste and execute</li>
</ul>
</li>
<li><strong>Mobile blocking and security popover</strong>
<ul>
<li>Detects mobile access and prompts victims to switch to desktop browsers and edit the core instructional component presented to them (security popover)</li>
</ul>
</li>
<li><strong>Advanced settings</strong>
<ul>
<li>Enables obfuscation techniques and automatic clipboard-copy JavaScript injection</li>
<li>Includes OS detection to tailor commands for Windows (Command Prompt or PowerShell) or macOS (Terminal)</li>
</ul>
</li>
</ul>
<figure id="attachment_160157" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-160157" style="width: 1000px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-160157 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/word-image-717079-160134-1.png" alt="Screenshots IUAM ClickFix generator, a &quot;professional phishing page configuration tool.&quot; Detailed settings include checkbox selections, numeric values, and dropdown menus for customization and security features." width="1000" height="767" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/word-image-717079-160134-1.png 1268w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/word-image-717079-160134-1-574x440.png 574w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/word-image-717079-160134-1-913x700.png 913w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/word-image-717079-160134-1-768x589.png 768w" sizes="(max-width: 1000px) 100vw, 1000px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-160157" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 1. User interface for the IUAM ClickFix Generator phishing kit.</figcaption></figure>
<h2><a id="post-160134-_ls18svs820v4"></a>From the Factory to the Frontlines: Real-World Campaigns</h2>
<p>Our analysis indicates that attackers have used the identified phishing kit (or closely related variants) to generate a range of ClickFix-themed phishing pages. These pages share a consistent visual theme spoofing the browser verification challenges commonly deployed by CDN and web security platforms. These pages also leverage tailored OS detection and command-copy mechanisms to socially engineer victims into manually executing malware payloads.</p>
<p>However, not all phishing pages identified share the same structure or behavior. While we confirmed at least one case where attackers delivered DeerStealer using a page this tool generated, we also saw several other phishing pages that differ slightly in technical implementation and visual design. These differences include:</p>
<ul>
<li>Structural variations in the HTML/DOM layout</li>
<li>Modified or entirely different command copy mechanisms</li>
<li>Lack of specific JavaScript logic (e.g., OS detection, dynamic instructions)</li>
<li>Simplified or inconsistent spoofing of browser challenge pages</li>
</ul>
<p>These discrepancies suggest there are multiple variants of the ClickFix kit, or there could be distinct phishing toolkits inspired by the same lure concept but built independently or derived from earlier versions.</p>
<p>Below are examples showcasing the range of ClickFix phishing pages we discovered, each demonstrating slightly different levels of sophistication, behavior and delivery mechanisms.</p>
<h3><a id="post-160134-_dxbacsxzeh35"></a>Campaign 1: The Windows-Only Attack (DeerStealer)</h3>
<p>In one campaign, attackers configured the kit for a focused attack on Windows users. The threat actor included no OS detection logic in this setup. As a result, they didn’t configure the page to provide alternative commands or specific instructions for macOS or other non-Windows users.</p>
<p>When a victim interacts with the CAPTCHA element (Figure 2) by clicking a checkbox to determine whether they are human, this action triggers a background JavaScript to copy a malicious PowerShell command to their clipboard. Simultaneously, a popover appears, instructing them to open the Windows Run dialog (by pressing Win+R), paste the content from their clipboard and run the command. Once they follow these instructions, the command downloads and runs a multi-stage batch script that ultimately installs the DeerStealer infostealer.</p>
<figure id="attachment_160168" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-160168" style="width: 1000px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-160168 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/word-image-720527-160134-2.png" alt="Screenshot of a Cloudflare verification CAPTCHA prompt asking the user to press specific keys to confirm they are not a robot. Instructions and a CAPTCHA ID are visible." width="1000" height="732" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/word-image-720527-160134-2.png 1714w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/word-image-720527-160134-2-601x440.png 601w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/word-image-720527-160134-2-957x700.png 957w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/word-image-720527-160134-2-768x562.png 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/word-image-720527-160134-2-1536x1124.png 1536w" sizes="(max-width: 1000px) 100vw, 1000px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-160168" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 2. Campaign 1 - ClickFix page delivering DeerStealer.</figcaption></figure>
<p>Figure 3 below shows the copied command we observed.</p>
<figure id="attachment_160179" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-160179" style="width: 1000px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-160179 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/word-image-724213-160134-3.png" alt="Screenshot of a command line script with a command to invoke a network request to a specified IP address and execute a batch file." width="1000" height="193" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/word-image-724213-160134-3.png 2048w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/word-image-724213-160134-3-786x152.png 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/word-image-724213-160134-3-1920x371.png 1920w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/word-image-724213-160134-3-768x149.png 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/word-image-724213-160134-3-1536x297.png 1536w" sizes="(max-width: 1000px) 100vw, 1000px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-160179" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 3. DOM structure showing the command copied to victim clipboard.</figcaption></figure>
<p>When executed, this command downloads a <a href="https://www.virustotal.com/gui/file/2b74674587a65cfc9c2c47865ca8128b4f7e47142bd4f53ed6f3cb5cf37f7a6b" target="_blank" rel="noopener">batch script</a> <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">cv.bat</span> (SHA256: <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">2b74674587a65cfc9c2c47865ca8128b4f7e47142bd4f53ed6f3cb5cf37f7a6b</span>) to the victim's temporary directory and immediately runs it.</p>
<p>Analysis of the batch script reveals a multi-stage process designed to download and execute a <a href="https://www.virustotal.com/gui/file/ead6b1f0add059261ac56e9453131184bc0ae2869f983b6a41a1abb167edf151" target="_blank" rel="noopener">malicious MSI file</a> (SHA256: <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">ead6b1f0add059261ac56e9453131184bc0ae2869f983b6a41a1abb167edf151</span>) identified as the DeerStealer infostealer.</p>
<h3><a id="post-160134-_7x43hq89clrc"></a>Campaign 2: Multi-Platform Attack (Odyssey Infostealer)</h3>
<p>In another case we observed (Figure 4), the threat actor deployed three variations of the phishing page. These all ultimately lead to the delivery of Odyssey infostealer for macOS users and an as-yet unidentified malware strain for Windows users. Despite these variations, the core structure of the phishing page remained consistent.</p>
<figure id="attachment_160190" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-160190" style="width: 614px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-160190 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/word-image-727488-160134-4.png" alt="Screenshot of a security verification page from speedtestcheck.org, displaying a message about unusual web traffic detected from the user's IP address. The page includes instructions on how to verify human identity by entering commands into a computer terminal, and features a &quot;I am not a robot&quot; checkbox and a &quot;Copy&quot; button for copying the command text." width="614" height="526" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/word-image-727488-160134-4.png 614w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/word-image-727488-160134-4-514x440.png 514w" sizes="(max-width: 614px) 100vw, 614px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-160190" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 4. Campaign 2 - ClickFix page delivering Odyssey for macOS.</figcaption></figure>
<p>Each version of the phishing page detects the victim’s operating system via JavaScript, specifically by parsing the browser’s <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">navigator.userAgent</span> string, and delivers a payload accordingly.</p>
<p>While the visible text (Figure 4) suggests a harmless string, clicking the Copy button executes JavaScript that places a malicious command into the clipboard, not the one visually displayed.</p>
<p>The specific commands and targets vary between different versions of this phishing page.</p>
<p><strong>Variation 1: Multi-platform Windows and macOS Payload<br />
</strong></p>
<p>In multi-platform variants, attackers serve Windows users a malicious PowerShell command designed to download and execute an unidentified malware strain. They serve macOS users a Base64-encoded command to deliver Odyssey (Figure 5).</p>
<figure id="attachment_160201" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-160201" style="width: 1000px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-160201 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/word-image-730205-160134-5.png" alt="Screenshot of a computer code snippet in a text editor displaying conditional statements in JavaScript that handle copy commands based on the user's operating system, including Mac, Windows, and an unknown OS. The code includes comments and command lines for each condition." width="1000" height="386" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/word-image-730205-160134-5.png 2048w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/word-image-730205-160134-5-786x304.png 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/word-image-730205-160134-5-1812x700.png 1812w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/word-image-730205-160134-5-768x297.png 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/word-image-730205-160134-5-1536x593.png 1536w" sizes="(max-width: 1000px) 100vw, 1000px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-160201" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 5. DOM structure showing a multi-platform example.</figcaption></figure>
<p>Examples of domains that hosted this variant include:</p>
<ul>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">tradingview.connect-app[.]us[.]com</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">treadingveew.dekstop-apps[.]com</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">treadingveew.last-desk[.]org</span></li>
</ul>
<h4><a id="post-160134-_9ryzrutvdwzp"></a>Variation 2: macOS-Targeted Variant with Windows Decoy and Fallback Handling</h4>
<p>In other variants that appear to be macOS-focused, macOS users receive a Base64-encoded command to deliver Odyssey. Windows users receive a PowerShell command as a benign decoy intended to complete the social engineering lure without delivering a payload. These PowerShell commands sometimes use domains with Cyrillic characters that visually mimic Latin ones to appear legitimate (Figure 6 and 7).</p>
<p>And for people using unknown operating systems (i.e., when OS detection fails), the phishing page displays a benign-looking command that also results in no malicious activity (Figure 6 and 7).</p>
<figure id="attachment_160212" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-160212" style="width: 1000px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-160212 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/word-image-734653-160134-6.png" alt="Screenshot of a code snippet involving variables and different commands related to CloudFlare." width="1000" height="104" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/word-image-734653-160134-6.png 2048w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/word-image-734653-160134-6-786x82.png 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/word-image-734653-160134-6-1920x200.png 1920w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/word-image-734653-160134-6-768x80.png 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/word-image-734653-160134-6-1536x160.png 1536w" sizes="(max-width: 1000px) 100vw, 1000px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-160212" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 6. DOM structure of the phishing page showing OS conditioned commands.</figcaption></figure>
<figure id="attachment_160223" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-160223" style="width: 1000px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-160223 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/word-image-737653-160134-7.png" alt="Screenshot of a code snippet featuring JavaScript commands used for terminal commands, to handle different operating systems, and a variable currentThemeIsDark focused on Windows OS." width="1000" height="126" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/word-image-737653-160134-7.png 2048w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/word-image-737653-160134-7-786x99.png 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/word-image-737653-160134-7-1920x243.png 1920w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/word-image-737653-160134-7-768x97.png 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/word-image-737653-160134-7-1536x194.png 1536w" sizes="(max-width: 1000px) 100vw, 1000px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-160223" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 7. DOM structure of the phishing page showing OS conditioned commands.</figcaption></figure>
<p>Examples of domains that hosted this variant include:</p>
<ul>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">claudflurer[.]com</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">teamsonsoft[.]com</span></li>
</ul>
<h4><a id="post-160134-_uwubfjtu75e0"></a>Variation 3: macOS Exclusive Delivering Odyssey Only</h4>
<p>Another variant appears to be exclusively macOS-focused, providing only a single Base64-encoded command that downloads and executes Odyssey, with no configurations for other operating systems (Figure 8).</p>
<figure id="attachment_160234" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-160234" style="width: 1000px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-160234 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/word-image-740616-160134-8.png" alt="Screenshot of a code snippet featuring JavaScript commands used for terminal commands." width="1000" height="60" data-srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/word-image-740616-160134-8.png 2048w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/word-image-740616-160134-8-786x47.png 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/word-image-740616-160134-8-1920x114.png 1920w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/word-image-740616-160134-8-768x46.png 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/word-image-740616-160134-8-1536x92.png 1536w" sizes="(max-width: 1000px) 100vw, 1000px" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-160234" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 8. macOS-focused example with no OS specification.</figcaption></figure>
<p>This command downloads and executes a macOS Odyssey infostealer. It also uses <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">nohup</span> bash, which starts a new Bash shell in the background that ignores hang ups (HUP signals), so it keeps running even if the terminal is closed.</p>
<p>Examples of domains or IP addresses that hosted this variant include:</p>
<ul>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">emailreddit[.]com</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">hxxps[:]//188.92.28[.]186</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">cloudlare-lndex[.]com</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">tradingviewen[.]com</span></li>
</ul>
<h2><a id="post-160134-_r4hnwfyeabe2"></a>Shared Origins and Developer Artifacts</h2>
<p>Despite differences in targeting logic and payload delivery URLs, all analyzed phishing pages in Campaign 2 share an identical underlying structure, including a consistent HTML layout and JavaScript function naming.</p>
<p>Furthermore, while the specific command-and-control (C2) server address varied between the pages, Our analysis confirmed that, although the specific command-and-control (C2) server address varied between pages, all were Odyssey C2 servers.</p>
<p>This consistency in both the page structure and C2 infrastructure strongly suggests that these variants are part of the same activity cluster and likely originate from a shared codebase or builder tool.</p>
<p>Odyssey is a malware-as-a-service (MaaS) offering operated by a cybercrime actor active on dark web forums such as Exploit and XSS, known to collaborate with other actors and affiliates. As such, it is plausible that these phishing page variations reflect customized deployments of a base toolkit distributed by the malware operator or their affiliates.</p>
<p>According to posts published by the actor who advertises and operates the Odyssey MaaS, the actor has allegedly supplied ClickFix-style lure pages to affiliates upon request. This further supports the theory that these variants originate from a common generator tool but are tailored per affiliate, campaign or individual preferences.</p>
<p>Additionally, some pages contained leftover developer comments written in Russian (Figure 9 and 10).</p>
<figure id="attachment_160245" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-160245" style="width: 718px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-160245 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/word-image-743312-160134-9.png" alt="A screenshot of computer code including a JavaScript function named notifyClick, which sends a click notification using the fetch API to 'stats.php'. The code includes a comment in Cyrillic characters that translates to 'Function for sending a click notification'." width="718" height="124" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-160245" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 9. Russian leftover developer comment.</figcaption></figure>
<p>English translation of this Russian comment in Figure 9: <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">Add a call to stats.php when the page loads</span>.</p>
<figure id="attachment_160256" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-160256" style="width: 756px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><img  class="wp-image-160256 lozad"  data-src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/10/word-image-745751-160134-10.png" alt="Screenshot of a comment in Cyrillic characters as part of a code snippet in a script tag that adds a 'stats.php' fetch call when a web page loads. " width="756" height="170" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-160256" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 10. Russian leftover developer comment.</figcaption></figure>
<p>English translation of the Russian comment in Figure 10: <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">Function for sending click notification</span>.</p>
<p>Ultimately, the structural consistency across all samples strongly indicates they were generated from a single, configurable phishing kit, with every malicious variant designed to deliver the Odyssey infostealer malware.</p>
<h2><a id="post-160134-_2an8ryq91inv"></a>Conclusion</h2>
<p>The discovery of the IUAM ClickFix Generator provides a rare glimpse into the tooling that lowers the barrier to entry for cybercriminals, enabling them to launch sophisticated, multi-platform attacks without deep technical expertise. The ClickFix technique's effectiveness relies on exploiting a user's instinct to follow onscreen instructions from what appears to be a trusted security provider.</p>
<p>This threat underscores the importance of user awareness and vigilance. Individuals and organizations should be cautious of any website that instructs them to manually copy and execute commands to prove they are human. This simple but deceptive social engineering tactic is a growing threat that turns a person’s actions into the primary infection vector.</p>
<h3><a id="post-160134-_lsbythhc3nz9"></a>Palo Alto Networks Protection and Mitigation</h3>
<p>Palo Alto Networks customers are better protected from the threats discussed above through the following products:</p>
<ul>
<li><a href="https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/advanced-url-filtering/administration" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Advanced URL Filtering</a> and <a href="https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/dns-security" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Advanced DNS Security</a> identify known domains and URLs associated with this activity as malicious.</li>
<li>The <a href="https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/wildfire" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Advanced WildFire</a> machine-learning models and analysis techniques have been reviewed and updated in light of the indicators shared in this research.</li>
<li><a href="https://docs-cortex.paloaltonetworks.com/p/XDR" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Cortex XDR</a> and <a href="https://docs-cortex.paloaltonetworks.com/p/XSIAM" target="_blank" rel="noopener">XSIAM</a> are designed to prevent the malware samples described in this post by employing the <a href="https://docs-cortex.paloaltonetworks.com/r/Cortex-XDR/Cortex-XDR-4.x-Documentation/Malware-protection" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Malware Prevention Engine</a>. This approach combines several layers of protection, including <a href="https://docs.paloaltonetworks.com/advanced-wildfire" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Advanced WildFire</a>, Behavioral Threat Protection and the Local Analysis module, to prevent both known and unknown malware from causing harm to endpoints. The mitigation methods implement malware protection based on different operating systems: Windows, macOS and Linux.</li>
</ul>
<p>If you think you may have been compromised or have an urgent matter, get in touch with the <a href="https://start.paloaltonetworks.com/contact-unit42.html">Unit 42 Incident Response team</a> or call:</p>
<ul>
<li>North America: Toll Free: +1 (866) 486-4842 (866.4.UNIT42)</li>
<li>UK: +44.20.3743.3660</li>
<li>Europe and Middle East: +31.20.299.3130</li>
<li>Asia: +65.6983.8730</li>
<li>Japan: +81.50.1790.0200</li>
<li>Australia: +61.2.4062.7950</li>
<li>India: 000 800 050 45107</li>
</ul>
<p>Palo Alto Networks has shared these findings with our fellow Cyber Threat Alliance (CTA) members. CTA members use this intelligence to rapidly deploy protections to their customers and to systematically disrupt malicious cyber actors. Learn more about the <a href="https://www.cyberthreatalliance.org" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Cyber Threat Alliance</a>.</p>

<td style="text-align: center;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">2025-06-22</span></td>
<td style="text-align: center;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">2025-06-24</span></td>
<td><span style="font-weight: 400;">Odyssey</span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="text-align: center;"><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">88.214.50[.]3</span></td>
<td style="text-align: center;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">2025-04-14</span></td>
<td style="text-align: center;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">2025-05-16</span></td>
<td><span style="font-weight: 400;">Odyssey</span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="text-align: center;"><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">45.146.130[.]132</span></td>
<td style="text-align: center;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">2025-07-01</span></td>
<td style="text-align: center;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">2025-07-28</span></td>
<td><span style="font-weight: 400;">Odyssey</span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="text-align: center;"><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">45.146.130[.]131</span></td>
<td style="text-align: center;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">2025-07-03</span></td>
<td style="text-align: center;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">2025-07-28</span></td>
<td><span style="font-weight: 400;">Odyssey</span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="text-align: center;"><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">185.93.89[.]62</span></td>
<td style="text-align: center;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">2025-07-29</span></td>
<td style="text-align: center;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">2025-09-18</span></td>
<td><span style="font-weight: 400;">Odyssey</span></td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
<p><span style="font-size: 10pt;">Table 2. IPv4 addresses for C2 servers.</span></p>
<p>Table 3 lists the fully qualified domain names (FQDNs) associated with the malware discussed in this article.</p>

<tr>
<td><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">365-drive[.]com</span></td>

</tbody>
</table>
<p><span style="font-size: 10pt;">Table 3. FQDNs associated with the malware discussed in this article.</span></p>
<p style="padding-left: 40px;"><strong>Note:</strong> In some cases, the ClickFix-style phishing page is not hosted on a domain the threat actor registered, but instead injected into a legitimate website that they’ve compromised. The actor adds a malicious JavaScript snippet that performs several DOM manipulations, including injecting the ClickFix phishing lure. They style this using Tailwind CSS, which overrides the site’s original layout and appearance to fully render the phishing content in place of the legitimate one.</p>
      
              </div>
              <!--<span class="post__date">Updated 7 October, 2025 at 1:38 PM PDT</span>-->
              <button class="l-btn back-to-top" id="backToTop" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="clickfix-generator-first-of-its-kind:back to top">Back to top</button>

              <div class="card-media " >
                              <figure>
                <img width="786" height="368" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/07/01_Business_email_compromise_Category_1920x900-786x368.jpg" class="lozad" alt="Pictorial representation of homograph attacks. 3D illustration of an open laptop displaying an envelope icon on the screen, accompanied by a smartphone and tablet, all set against a dark background with neon lighting." decoding="async" srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/07/01_Business_email_compromise_Category_1920x900-786x368.jpg 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/07/01_Business_email_compromise_Category_1920x900-1493x700.jpg 1493w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/07/01_Business_email_compromise_Category_1920x900-768x360.jpg 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/07/01_Business_email_compromise_Category_1920x900-1536x720.jpg 1536w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/07/01_Business_email_compromise_Category_1920x900.jpg 1920w" sizes="(max-width: 786px) 100vw, 786px" />                </figure> 
                            </div>
              <div class="card-content">
                <div class="card-content__wrapper">
                  <a class="card-category" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/threat-research/" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="clickfix-generator-first-of-its-kind:related-resources:The Ηоmоgraph Illusion: Not Everything Is As It Seems:Threat Research"><span class=""><img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/icon-threat-research.svg" alt=" category icon">Threat Research</span></a>                        <span class="post-pub-date"><time datetime="2025-07-25T21:00:13+00:00">July 25, 2025</time></span>
                  <a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/homograph-attacks/" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="clickfix-generator-first-of-its-kind:related-resources:The Ηоmоgraph Illusion: Not Everything Is As It Seems">
                    <h4 class="post-title">The Ηоmоgraph Illusion: Not Everything Is As It Seems</h4>
                  </a>
                  <ul class="card-tags" role="list">
				<li role="listitem">
					<a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/genai/" title="GenAI" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="clickfix-generator-first-of-its-kind:related-resources:The Ηоmоgraph Illusion: Not Everything Is As It Seems:GenAI">GenAI</a>

					<a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/phishing/" title="phishing" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="clickfix-generator-first-of-its-kind:related-resources:The Ηоmоgraph Illusion: Not Everything Is As It Seems:phishing">Phishing</a>

                    <h4 class="post-title">Investigating Infrastructure and Tactics of Phishing-as-a-Service Platform Sniper Dz</h4>
                  </a>
                  <ul class="card-tags" role="list">
				<li role="listitem">
					<a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/phishing-kit/" title="Phishing Kit" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="clickfix-generator-first-of-its-kind:related-resources:Investigating Infrastructure and Tactics of Phishing-as-a-Service Platform Sniper Dz:Phishing Kit">Phishing Kit</a>
